Headline.Para: Poor villagers in Langkawi mull over who will be the best caretaker

LeadPara.Para: With its haphazard maze of shabby houses and broken roads, Kampung Bukit Malut in Langkawi stands in stark contrast to the island's pristine beaches and calm blue sea.
Water flows weakly from taps and electricity is wired to homes through tangled extension cords.

TailParas.Para: At least three big fires have broken out there. The last, in 2015, gutted 150 houses, forcing villagers to camp in jerry-built tents on a nearby football field since then.
Village imam Kadir Mustafa, 58, told The Straits Times that the residents had to pool money to build their own jetty out of firewood, as well as footpaths and houses.

"Look, so much trash," he said, pointing to the heaps of empty water bottles and food waste clogging the coastline before adding: "If the government can't clear it, why not pay to outsource the job to others?
"There's no development here. Please take care of our welfare, don't play favouritism and treat us like we are nothing."

This poverty-stricken, neglected village has become the focus of attention ahead of the upcoming Malaysia election, drawing politicians from rival factions armed with promises of a better future - and warnings about bad choices.

A three-cornered fight is expected, but if party flags showing the blue weighing scales and the red hibiscus strung across the main street are anything to go by, the contest has been narrowed down to two contenders: the Barisan Nasional ruling coalition, with its weighing scales logo; and Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (PPBM), led by Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad and represented by the hibiscus. The hibiscus is Malaysia's national flower. The third contender is Parti Islam SeMalaysia.
Dr Mahathir started the ball rolling with a visit to the BN stronghold in January, telling residents they had been sidelined, and urging them to switch sides.

"There is poor supply of water, electricity in Bukit Malut, which results in frequent fires. During the last fire, about three, four years ago, all the state government did was set up tents (for the victims); until now they are living in the tents," he was quoted as saying.

Three weeks later, Kedah Menteri Besar Ahmad Bashah Md Hanipah also made a trip to the village, his hands full of goodies: a RM215,000 (S$72,600) budget to build a mosque, regular electricity and water supply to households, and RM5,000 each to 84 families whose houses were destroyed in the fire three years ago.

Now, villagers are mulling if they should stay loyal to Umno, the main party in the government, or support Dr Mahathir, who they say was instrumental in bringing their families back to Kedah in the 1980s.
The Straits Times understands that most of over 3,000 people there are descendants of returning Kedahan survivors who worked on the Death Railway in Myanmar during the Japanese occupation in 1942.
Gardener Sahara Othman, 43, felt the government is the village's best caretaker, as it has the resources, but fisherman Abu Bakar Kadir, 30, said he is choosing Dr Mahathir.

Mr Abu Bakar said he has to share his electricity with several houses. He collects rainwater for cooking and cleaning, as the current supply is inadequate, adding: "We also worry about fire because power trips happen so often. All we want is a safe living environment."

Fisherman Zaidi Ali, 40, said the RM5,000 he received was not enough to rebuild his house. "But it's still money, so I can't say the government hasn't helped. As for Tun, I have seen him around but don't know him well. I really don't know who I should vote for."

Article.Art: Blue BN flags and red PPBM flags at the entrance of Kampung Bukit Malut in Langkawi. Dr Mahathir has urged the BN stronghold to switch sides, pointing to a fire three years ago, the victims of which are still living in tents. Meanwhile, the government has given the fire victims money, as well as allocated a budget for the village to build a mosque and electricity and water supply.
